text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with pastry cream that's right as
promised i'm going to show you our new
and hopefully improved pastry cream
recipe and while I did and do enjoy our
old version I think this new formula is
a little bit lighter maybe a little bit
easier and definitely probably better
tasting because we're gonna splurge and
use a real vanilla bean so that's pretty
exciting
and we'll get to that in a few minutes
but first we have to take care of the
non exciting stuff also known as our egg
sugar and cornstarch mixture so for that
in a mixing bowl we'll start with one
whole large egg to which we will add two
large egg yolks
okay so separate two eggs add just the
yolks and then of course you can save
those whites for a meringue or to
clarify consummating which reminds me we
need to do that video but anyway we're
gonna need one whole egg plus two yolks
to which we will add a little bit of
salt plus way more than a little bit of
sugar and then last but not least we
will add our cornstarch and then we'll
take a whisk and give this a very very
thorough mixing and by the way there's
three different ways you can go with the
starch here you can go with just
cornstarch just flour or a combination
and I've tried them all and my personal
favorite is the pure cornstarch versions
which while slightly more temperamental
does deliver a little cleaner pure
vanilla flavor I find the ones that use
flour a little easier to work with but
you get that little bit of paste enos on
your palate that I think kind of takes
away from the whole effect but anyway
like I said we will take a whisk and we
will give this a very thorough mixing
and what's going to happen here our
mixture is gonna turn from something
that's kind of pasty and golden in color
to something lighter in texture and much
paler in appearance which hopefully
you're getting a good look at here and
besides the obvious color change one way
you know you're probably done is when
that mixture dripping off the whisk kind
of stays up on top of the surface for a
second before disappearing or you see
that so that is looking very nice right
there and then once that's been
accomplished we'll simply set that aside
and move on to scalding our milk so on
some kind of heavy-duty saucepan we will
need two cups of whole milk plus 1 whole
scraped vanilla bean and there it is I
know it doesn't look that exciting but
it is and while does look like an old
green bean the fell behind the stove
like three years ago it's actually a
dried seed pod from a tropical orchid
and what we'll need to do to work with
this is take a knife and split it right
down the middle and the reason for that
is all the goodness is inside so what
we'll do once that split is simply
scrape against that cut side with the
back of our knife and what you're going
to get is something that almost looks
like a black tower but it's actually
like hundreds of thousands of little
black seeds so what we'll do is split
and scrape one bean which we will add to
our milk and by the way don't worry if
you see a few fibers here and there
that's just part of the pod and won't be
a problem since we're gonna strain this
at the end oh and by the way don't throw
away that scrape pod I'm gonna tell you
what to do that in the blog post but
anyway once we've added our vanilla to
our milk we can head to the stove where
we're gonna place this over medium-high
heat and all we're gonna do other than
giving it a stir once in a while is wait
for this to just start to simmer not
boil just barely starts to simmer and as
this warms up all those millions of
little vanilla seeds are gonna separate
and your milks gonna look kind of dirty
but don't worry it's all part of the
show it's gonna be fine and like I said
all we're gonna do is leave this on
medium high stirring occasionally until
it just barely starts to simmer okay so
don't go anywhere don't answer the door
don't answer the phone
unless you're cooking with your
Bluetooth in your ear which would be
kind of sad but anyway the point is to
pay attention until we start to see a
few small bubbles start to break the
surface all right so that's perfect
right there and then what we'll do once
our milk has just barely come to a
simmer is remove it from the heat and
carefully whisk it into our egg mixture
oh by the way to keep your bowl steady
don't be afraid to twist up and make a
ring out of a damp kitchen towel and set
the bowl on that but anyway we're gonna
whisk in our hot milk and I'll generally
start with one small splash you give
that a couple stirs before dumping the
rest in and what we'll do is give that a
mix for about a minute and once that set
we'll simply transfer that back into our
saucepan because to finish our pastry
cream what we're gonna have to do is
bring this back to the stove and place
it on medium-low heat and cook it
stirring until it thickens up which is
only gonna take a couple minutes and you
may have heard me say before hey you
might even have the t-shirt but you may
have heard me say before that a
hollandaise can sense fear well so can a
pastry cream so I want you to place this
on medium low heat and start whisking
with no fear okay clear eyes and a full
heart will also help but mostly no fear
the reason not to be afraid is because
really nothing can go wrong here you
were simply gonna stir with a whisk
until the mixture thickens all that's
gonna happen is it's gonna come back to
temperature and after a few minutes it
will slowly but surely start to thicken
up and I'll be honest I told you to use
medium low but because I've done so many
and I'm kind of reckless I actually used
medium heat to save a little time so if
you want a temp fate and go with a
little higher heat feel free
you either cuba gooding of what's
basically just vanilla pudding but
anyway whether you're on medium low or
medium we're simply gonna cook that
stirring until it thickens up so right
about here we're getting close but I
wanted to give it a few more seconds
until it looked a little something like
this and as soon as that level of
thickness is reached what we need to do
is turn off the heat immediately okay if
you continue to cook something that's
thickened with cornstarch it can
actually end up runny once it's cool so
very important as soon as this thickens
up we need to remove it from the heat
and then what we'll want to do is let
this sit for about five minutes cooling
down slightly before we mix in our
butter so that's what I did and then
about five minutes later we will finish
this up by tossing in our cold chunks of
butter and whisking constantly until
they disappear home by the way I
mentioned hollandaise earlier which of
course is a sauce featuring emulsified
butter well believe it or not we're
actually doing the same thing here and
then once this is chilled that butters
gonna tighten up and not only will it
help thicken this it's also going to add
some richness any more luxurious
mouthfeel and then what we'll do once
our butters been incorporated is passed
this through a fine mesh strainer and
theoretically this is to remove any
particles of egg that got overcooked but
I never have any of those and you
probably won't either so really this is
to catch any fibers from our vanilla
bean scraping and or other impurities
and yes in case you're wondering all
those little vanilla seeds are gonna
pass through the strainer and as you can
see I was left with just a few pieces of
pod and that's it once our pastry cream
is strained it's done and totally ready
not to use because while gorgeous and
pretty delicious this is still obviously
too warm to use so taste it if you want
but before we can use this we need to
wrap it up and chill it thoroughly and
one trick so this doesn't form a skin is
we'll press that plastic down right onto
the surface I usually do that no matter
what I'm wrapping but here it even makes
more sense so we'll go ahead and wrap
that up as shown and I went ahead and
pop that in the fridge
- my English cucumber and German butter
hey don't judge me but anyway we're
gonna pop that in the fridge until like
I said it's completely and thoroughly
chilled so this was mine a few hours
later and we'll unwrap that and see how
we did and by the way by changing the
amount of liquid and/or cornstarch you
can make this a lot thinner or a lot
thicker depending on what you're gonna
use it for but for me this thickness is
perfect for all purposes okay we've
already seen it using a Napoleon not too
long ago but it's also fabulous for
filling things like cream puffs and yes
I have shown you how to make these sort
of I believe that would be our cream
puffs Swan video but anyway besides
Napoleon's and chocolate covered cream
puffs there are so many uses for this
stuff especially this time of year you
know pies tarts layer cakes etc but have
you said that a chocolate covered cream
puff is hard to beat so let me go ahead
and take a bite of this so I can finish
this video with a shot of something
besides plain pastry cream in a bowl and
oh man was that amazing and I don't even
really like desserts so imagine how much
you're gonna enjoy this but anyway
that's it our new and improved pastry
cream and contrary to what you read on
the internet not a very hard recipe to
make especially using our simple
technique just remember no fear so I
really do hope you give this a try soon
head over to food wishes comm for all
the ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
[Music]
you
